This has been sitting on the queue for a while. @Sebastien Gouezel suggested a different definition, which I did not get to work and I think might be impossible to work. The reason is that there is a theorem that says that if one defines the adjoint via the graph (we can't do this because we don't have a inner_product_space structure for products), then the graph gives rise to an operator if and only if the domain is dense.
However, I think I have a usable definition that does not introduce artifical new structures,fact or any other nonsense.

@Moritz Doll can you explain why the other idea doesn't work? That is, taking the adjoint of T ⊕ 0 where 0 acts on the orthogonal complement of T.domain. It may be the case that this is just painful in comparison to what you have, and adjoints of non-densely-defined operators just don't arise in practice, which is an acceptable answer. (Also note, it would be possible to recover the T ⊕ 0 version from what you have if someone wanted such a thing.)

Maybe it technically does work, but as I said there is definition of the adjoint that we cannot implement at the moment, because we don't have L2-prod of Hilbert spaces and that definition does not produce an operator if T is not densely defined. Therefore, I would argue that everything else is just a junk value and since we can define the domain independently of the property that T is densely defined my proposed definition is a good one (maybe not the best, but this might be a perfect is the enemy of good thing). I would think that it is more convenient to have a working definition for now and if find out that some other definition is better suited I am happy to refactor.
Thanks, I'll have a more in-depth look at the PR tomorrow.
Sorry @Moritz Doll, my time was eaten and the weekend was busy. I promise I'll get to it tonight.
